questions.question: The logo below represents which of the following health programs?

options.B: National program for control of blindness and visual impairment

questions.question: In the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP), which level of prevention involves early diagnosis and prompt treatment of leprosy cases to prevent disabilities and deformities?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Secondary prevention Explanation Secondary prevention in the context of NLEP focuses on early detection through active case detection campaigns and timely treatment to prevent the progression of leprosy, thereby minimizing disabilities and deformities among affected individuals. Primary Level of Prevention Health Education SPARSH program uses a cartoon girl known as Sapna who is in a village spreading awareness on Leprosy. Secondary Level of Prevention Early diagnosis and treatment Detection is done by ASHA ASHA gets cash incentives Tertiary Prevention Treatment of drug-resistant leprosy Disability limitation and rehabilitation Reconstructive surgeries for deformities Crutches to walk Microcellular rubber footwear Self-care kits Sparsh program: Create awareness about leprosy using Sapna as a mascot Provides prophylaxis to close contacts The concept of Sapna was adopted from Meena. It is for child rights and Impairment given by UNICEF and was successful and adopted by Leprosy Trust Mission to spread awareness. SET Centres : (Survey , education and treatment centre) : 1 SET centre / 25000 population Attached to PHC. Dose of rifampicin as prophylaxis (single dose): ≥ 15 years 600 mg 10-14 years 450 mg 6-9 years 300 mg Children <20 kg 10-15 mg/kg

questions.question: Which of the following is a primary indicator of leprosy cases?

options.A: Proportion of new cases correctly diagnosed
options.C: Number of relapses during a year
options.D: Proportion of MB cases among new cases

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Treatment completion rate Explanation: The treatment completion rate is a primary indicator. Monitoring and evaluation of leprosy cases: Primary Indicators (Core indicator) Annual new case detection rate: Most important Epidemiological indicator. Treatment completion rate (cohort analysis). Indicators for Case Detection Proportion of new cases with Grade II disability Proportion of female cases among new cases Proportion of cases <15 years (child) among new cases. Proportion of MB cases among new cases. (Option D) Indicators for Quality of Services Proportion of defaulters Proportion of new cases correctly diagnosed (Option A) Number of relapses during a year (Option C) Proportion of cases with new disabilities Other indicators: Most important operational Indicator: Grade 2 disability Indicator Most important health awareness/ Leprosy awareness indicator: Grade 2 disability Indicator. Reference: https://cltri.gov.in/AboutLeprosy/NLEP_indicators.pdf

questions.question: Which of the following defines Grade 2 disability in leprosy according to the WHO Disability Grading System? function.

options.A: Grade 2 disability involves no impairment of hand or foot function.
options.B: Grade 2 disability includes severe visible deformities and impairment of hand or foot function.
options.C: Grade 2 disability refers to mild visible deformities without any functional impairment.
options.D: Grade 2 disability indicates moderately visible deformities with slight impairment of hand or foot

questions.explanation: foot function. hand or foot function. Explanation: Grade 2 disability is characterized by severe visible deformities and significant impairment of hand or foot function. Grades of disability in Leprosy Grade 0 Absence of disability (no anesthesia) and no visible damage or deformities on eyes, hands and feet. Muscle power is normal. Grade 1 Loss of the protective ability of the eyes, hands or feet, but no visible damage or deformities. Muscle power is normal. Grade 2 Presence of deformities or visible damage to the eyes, hands, or feet. Muscle power is weak or paralyzed, a lid gap is present in the eyes. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7058852/ http://www.clinicalestablishments.gov.in/WriteReadData/516.pdf

questions.question: What is the primary goal of the initiative "Leprosy Mukt Bharat"? 2025.

options.A: To eradicate leprosy from India completely by 2027.
options.B: To reduce the prevalence of leprosy cases in India by 50% by 2025.
options.C: To provide free treatment and rehabilitation services to all leprosy patients in India until 2030
options.D: To raise awareness about leprosy and reduce the stigma associated with the disease in India before

questions.explanation: Leprosy Mukt Bharat 2027: To eradicate leprosy by 2027. Features: Early detection (based on 2-level prevention). Free-of-cost treatment to prevent the development of disabilities and deformities. Medical rehabilitation of those with existing deformities. New additions: Welfare allowance - Raised from Rs.8000 to Rs.12000 for patients undergoing reconstructive surgeries. Enhance awareness regarding the stigma surrounding Leprosy. Reference: https://pib.gov.in/PressReleasePage.aspx?PRID=1894687#:~:text=%E2%80%9CIndia%20is%20makin g%20progress%20and,Health%20and%20Family%20Welfare%2C%20Dr . https://dghs.gov.in/WriteReadData/use rfiles/file/Leprosy%20New/NSP%20%20Roadmap%20for%20Leprosy%202023-2027.pdf

questions.question: Match the type of visual impairment with the corresponding visual acuity criteria based on the NPCB classification: Type of Visual Impairment Visual Acuity Criteria 1. Low Vision A. Visual acuity of less than 3/60 to 1/60 2. Economic Blindness B. No perception of light 3. Social Blindness C. Visual acuity of less than 6/18 to 6/60 4. Manifest Blindness D. Visual acuity of less than 6/60 to 3/60 5. Absolute Blindness E. Visual acuity of less than 1/60 to the perception of light
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-E, 5-B Explanation: NPCB Classification of Visual Impairment The National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India defines blindness as "visual acuity of <3/60 in a better eye with best possible correction" and central visual field <10 degrees. The NPCB further categorizes visual impairment as: Classification Visual Acuity Visual Impairment Visual acuity of less than 6/18 in the better eye with available correction Low Vision Visual acuity of less than 6/18 to 6/60 Economic Blindness Visual acuity of less than 6/60 to 3/60 Social Blindness Visual acuity of less than 3/60 to 1/60 Manifest Blindness Visual acuity of less than 1/60 to the perception of light Absolute Blindness No perception of light WHO Classification of Visual Impairment The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as "visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent". The International Classification of Disease 11 (2018) classifies vision impairment into distance and near-presenting vision impairment Classification Visual Acuity Mild Distance Vision Impairment Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12 Moderate Distance Vision Impairment Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18 Severe Distance Vision Impairment Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60 Blindness Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60 Near Vision Impairment Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or M0.8 at 40 cm with existing correction Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 456-457

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a history of progressively worsening vision over the past few years. On examination, she is found to have significant scarring of the inner eyelids, leading to an inward turning of the eyelashes that scrapes against the cornea. What is the most likely cause of her preventable blindness?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Trachoma Explanation: Based on the above scenario, the patient is most likely diagnosed with Trachoma. Trachoma: A Chronic infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis most commonly by serovars A, B, Ba, C leading to eyelid scarring, trichiasis, and corneal opacities. M/C cause of preventable blindness in adults is Trachoma Trachoma - WHO classification: TF - Trachomatous inflammation - follicular TI - Trachomatous inflammation - intense TS - Trachomatous scarring TT - Trachomatous trichiasis CO - Corneal Opacity SAFE Strategy The WHO's GET 2020 program (Global Elimination of Trachoma by 2020), has adopted the SAFE strategy for prophylaxis against trachoma infection and prevention of blindness, which includes: S: Surgery (Tertiary prevention) A: Antibiotic use (Secondary prevention) F: Facial hygiene (Primary prevention), and E: Environmental changes (Primordial prevention). Option A- Cataract : Clouding of the lens; age-related, unrelated to eyelash or corneal changes. Option B- Glaucoma : Damage to the optic nerve, usually associated with high intraocular pressure, leading to vision loss without eyelash or corneal changes. It is most common. M/C causes of curable blindness are cataract, refractive errors, and glaucoma. Option D- Vitamin A Deficiency: Can lead to night blindness and corneal scarring; not associated with trichiasis or repeated infections as in trachoma. Vit. A deficiency is the most common cause of preventable blindness in children. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no, 456-457 https://www.who.int/health-topics/trachoma#tab=tab_1 https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12346157/

questions.question: Match the following Tier against the corresponding number of units in accordance with the proposed four-tier structure under Vision 2020. Tier Number of Units A. Apex 1. 20,000 B. Centres of Excellence 2. 200 C. Training Centres 3. 2 D. Service Centres 4. 2000 E. Vision Centres 5. 20
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) A-3, B-5, C-2, D-4, E-1 Explanation: Proposed structure for Vision 2020, NPCB: Tier Number of Units Population Norms Components Centres of Excellence 20 1/50 million Professional Leadership Strategy development Continued Medical Education (CME) Laying of standards and quality assurance Research Training Centres 200 1/5 million Tertiary eye care including retinal surgery, corneal transplantation, glaucoma surgery, etc. Training and CME Service Centres 2000 1/500000 Cataract Surgery Other common eye surgeries Facilities for refraction Referral services Vision Centres 20,000 1/50000 Refraction and prescription of glasses Primary eye care School eye screening programme Screening and referral services

questions.question: Which is true regarding the health programme in the logo below?

options.A: It provides health insurance coverage only for rural populations.
options.B: Benefits under PM-JAY are restricted to government hospitals.
options.C: PM-JAY covers up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year for hospitalisation.
options.D: The scheme primarily focuses on providing primary healthcare services.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) PM-JAY covers up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year for hospitalisation. hospitalisation, treatment, and certain follow-up care. Features of the PM-JAY scheme: PM-JAY provides health insurance coverage for both rural and urban populations across India. (Option A) The scheme ensures cashless access to hospitalisation services. There are no restrictions based on family size, age, or gender. All pre-existing health conditions are included in the coverage. The benefits can be used nationwide at all hospitals in the network. (Option B) The plan covers 1685 procedures, including treatment, food, medicines, supplies, and diagnostic services. PM-JAY primarily focuses on providing coverage for secondary and tertiary care hospitalisation. (Option D) PM-JAY covers hospitalisation and treatment expenses and follow-up care up to three days before hospital admission and 15 days after discharge.

questions.question: A senior physician working at a government medical college in a rural area has observed a significant lack of advanced medical facilities and infrastructure in her institution. As a result, many patients are referred to urban centres for specialised care. Which government program addresses these disparities?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Pradhan Mantri Swasthya Suraksha Yojana Explanation: Pradhan Mantri Swasthya Suraksha Yojana (PMSSY) focuses on upgrading medical institutions in India by establishing new AIIMS and improving existing government medical colleges. It aims to address regional disparities in healthcare access and enhance medical education and research capabilities nationwide. Objectives: The goals are to address regional disparities in access to affordable and reliable tertiary healthcare services and enhance the infrastructure for high-quality medical education nationwide. (Option B) Pradhan Mantri Jan Dhan Yojana: This scheme promotes financial inclusion by ensuring every household can access basic banking services and financial literacy. (Option C) PMSSN (Pradhan Mantri Swasthya Suraksha Nidhi): Dedicated to advancing access to universal and affordable healthcare by ensuring readily available additional resources. (Option D) Jan Aushadhi scheme: Provides quality generic medicines at affordable prices through dedicated Jan Aushadhi stores.

questions.question: What level of prevention strategy does the concept of SAPNA come under in the prevention of leprosy?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Primary level of prevention Explanation: The concept of Sapna and Meena comes under the Primary level of prevention- Health Education. Sapna is a concept (mascot) designed and developed using a common girl living in a community, who spreads awareness and educates people about leprosy. This concept of Sapna is adopted from Meena, given by UNICEF for Child rights and impairment. This concept is also adopted by the Sparsh Programme to create awareness about leprosy. Primary Level of Prevention Health Education SPARSH program uses a cartoon girl known as Sapna who is in a village spreading awareness on Leprosy. Secondary Level of Prevention ( Option B) Early diagnosis and treatment Detection is done by ASHA ASHA gets cash incentives Tertiary Prevention ( Option C) Treatment of drug-resistant leprosy Disability limitation and rehabilitation Reconstructive surgeries for deformities Crutches to walk Microcellular rubber footwear Self-care kits Preventing overuse of diagnostic and treatment options available is quaternary prevention (Option D). Reference: https://dghs.gov.in/content/1329_1_Leprosy.aspx?format=Print&format=Print#:~:text=%E2%80%9CS apna%E2%80%9D%20is%20a%20concept%20
